author: voith
content:
<@!689161464829050960> <@!543900561460822016> 
I am interested in contributing to `eth1.0-specs`. <@!364458974906548225>  pointed me to your repo to get started. Also, I'm guessing that the two of you belong to the quilt team(Please correct me if I'm wrong).
I was planning to integrate `ethereum/tests` fixtures into the project, but it seems like there's already a PR for it? 
However, I could not find any issues on the repo that I could pick up. Do you mind creating issues so that we can coordinate? I want to make sure that we don't duplicate work.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@564718359304863744> I don't think Sam is the right person to talk to (unless they are working on a stealth project)?  Lightclient is tangentially related to eth1.0-specs, but you'll probably get better feedback in <#746566142700814426> which is likely the best place to find people to talk to about that repository.

author: voith
content:
I was guessing from the commits and the activity in this repo:
https://github.com/quilt/eth1.0-specs/commits/pyspec
And thanks for pointing me to the <#746566142700814426> channel.

author: samwilsn
content: I wouldn't exactly call it a stealth project üòõ

author: lightclient
content: shhshshh didn't we already discuss the first rule of the specs project?

author: samwilsn
content: > Correct - Describe the intended behavior of the Ethereum blockchain, and any deviation from that is a bug.

author: djrtwo
content: Challenge! Plug a minimum viable version of your project into the `ExectionEngine` protocol in the eth2 merge specs

content: FYI, here are the trie tests I showed <@!543900561460822016> this morning: https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/TrieTests
